qas.question: What was the origin of Hindu philosophy?
How many main systems of Hindu philosophy are there?
What are the main orthodox systems of Hindu philosophy called?
What is the accepted source of knowledge in the Astika system?
What are the non-orthodox Indian philosophies that do not accept Vedas called?
Which philosophy do both nastika and Astika philosophies accept?

context: Hindu philosophy refers to a group of darśanas (philosophies, world views, teachings) that emerged in <a0_0>ancient India<a0_0/>. The mainstream Hindu philosophy includes <a1_0><b5_0>six<b5_0/><a1_0/> systems (ṣaḍdarśana) – Samkhya, Yoga, Nyaya, Vaisheshika, Mimamsa and Vedanta. These are also called the <a2_0>Astika<a2_0/> (orthodox) philosophical traditions and are those that accept the <a3_0><b6_0>Vedas<b6_0/><a3_0/> as authoritative, important source of knowledge.[note 1][note 2] Ancient and medieval India was also the source of philosophies that share philosophical concepts but rejected the <b7_0>Vedas<b7_0/>, and these have been called <a4_0>nāstika<a4_0/> (<b8_0>heterodox<b8_0/> or non-orthodox) Indian philosophies. Nāstika Indian philosophies include Buddhism, Jainism, Cārvāka, Ājīvika, and others.
